message: In Python 2.7, I had some code that l looked like this (assume `right` is a list of dictionaries): right = {r.get(join_key): r for r in right}. When I run this same code in 2.5, I get a syntax error. What feature or change is it in 2.7 that makes this work?
you can kinda do a dict comprehension in 2.5
right = dict([(key, val) for key, val in right.items()])
@keegan Thanks! I knew how to fix it, but I wasn't sure why it was broken. Usually the other way around.
or just dict(derp for derp in right.items())
